Award.AwardTitle: Searches for New Phenomena with High Energy Particle Colliders
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Northern Illinois University group is completing its transition from the D0 experiment at Fermilab to the ATLAS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) as its core program. On ATLAS, Northern Illinois has operational responsibilities and electronics upgrades for hadron calorimetry (the ATLAS TileCal) and in simulation and algorithm development for the Fast TracKer (FTK) Trigger. These activities are central to the improved performance of ATLAS as the luminosity of the LHC increases. The NIU program of physics analysis focuses on studies of top quarks, vector bosons (W/Z), and direct photon production. They are also involved in the search for the decays of Higgs bosons into tau leptons, which could be an indicator of new, Beyond-the-Standard-Model phenomena.

The Northern Illinois group continues to be very active in detector development, particularly in the domain of calorimetry and muon detection, and has joined the Fermilab Mu2e experiment, among whose objectives is the search for muon conversion into electrons and hence lepton number violation.

Outreach to K-12 teachers and the general public is an integral part of the Northern Illinois program. The group initiated physics outreach on the campus in 2001, a program of effort that is now merged into the university's STEM outreach program. And, since 2008, the group has maintained an active center for QuarkNet, involving teachers and students in hands-on experimentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project has several important components, as summarized below.

Intellectual Merit: Toward exploration of basic science, the award enabled members of the NIU team to participate in the ATLAS experiment at CERN, the D0 and Mu2e experiments at Fermilab, and generic detector R&D at NIU. During the project period, the ATLAS experiment, built and operated by an international consortium of thousands of physicists, engineers, technicians and students, collected proton-proton collision data at the world's highest ever energies - up to 13 trillion electron-volts - delivered by the Large Hadron Collider located at CERN (Genava, Switzerland). The analysis of this data resulted in significant improvements in our understanding of the laws of Nature at the energy frontier. Although no new particles or phenomena were observed since the discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012, detailed studies of the production mechanisms, mass, and other properties of the Higgs boson, the top quark, the W and Z bosons - particles that cannot be produced at any other facility in operation - have refined our knowledge of the Standard Model of Particle Physics and informed future directions of research. These resulted in hundreds of publications in peer-reviewed journals. Members of the NIU team contributed to the operation of the ATLAS detector, analysis of data collected with it, and R&D of future upgrades.

The D0 experiment at Fermilab’s Tevatron proton-antiproton collider, another very large collaborative project, had stopped taking new data some time before, but analysis of data collected during its many years of operation continued and resulted in several publications in peer-reviewed journals. NIU team-members played leading roles in these analyses.

The Mu2e experiment at Fermilab will search for muon-to-electron conversions without creation or annihilation of any other particles in the process. Undertaken by a collaboration of 30+ universities and national laboratories in the US and abroad, the project at the intensity frontier was in the design and prototyping stage during this period. Members of the NIU team made major contributions to design optimization through simulation and prototyping of key detector technologies.

The detector R&D effort at NIU culminated in practical realization of finely segmented plastic scintillator-based calorimeters read out by solid-state photodetectors coupled directly to the half-dollar-size “cells”. Such technology holds huge potential for application in future detectors in high-energy particle physics as well as other areas such as medical imaging.

Broader Impact: Toward education and preparation of highly-skilled workforce with strong foundation and innovative experience in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM), which is essential for the US to continue to lead global advances in those areas, all of the above projects involved graduate and undergraduate students, as well as junior scientists. As valued team-members, they gained the theoretical and technical knowledge only, as well as training to function productively in team settings. After requisite training, many of them served in limited leadership roles, where their responsibilities included coordinating and liaising with others in complex organizational structures. All of the graduate students who completed their degrees as members of the NIU team during this project period – four doctoral and seven master’s - either went on to pursue higher studies (enrolling in PhD programs after completing their MS) or found gainful employment in their areas of choice in academia or industry. The group’s research also involved nine undergraduate students, four of whom were directly supported by this grant. While most of the graduate and undergraduate students were from the Physics department, some were from Engineering.

Toward outreach to the society at large, members of the NIU team supported by this award led and/or participated in several highly successful initiatives during the project period. About 100 students from area high schools, along with their science teachers, were attracted to the QuarkNet center at NIU, where the PI acts as the chief mentor, and whose activities include a day-long masterclass in spring, a week-long stipend-paid hands-on experimentation workshop in summer, hosting a booth at the fall STEMfest at NIU, and, for a selected few, stipend-paid 6-8 weeks of summer internship. One of the co-PI’s served on NIU’s STEM Outreach Committee, helping in planning and delivery of a variety of events. Both senior and junior members of the group visited local schools, gave public lectures, appeared in online media, served as volunteer at the Ask-a-Scientist open-house events at Fermilab, and welcomed visitors to tours of the Physics department, laboratory facilities, and the observatory operated by the HEP group, at NIU.

Outcomes of the activities described above include developing technologies and workforce for fields that touch our everyday lives – from education to medicine, from data-mining and other areas of information technology to homeland security, from financial markets to patent law. Last, but not the least, the successful international collaborations serve as model productive partnerships in the public sector to promote world peace.
